div.p: 15. I— IV. VI. Wednesday

My cough, disables me for sleeping, almost the whole night— I had retired to bed at 1/2 past 9 last evening— At one this morning I awoke, and had no prospect of further sleep till day-light—nor then— So I rose—dressed myself and found in the Lady’s cabin, a table and candles, which enabled me to write—and I wrote accordingly till 4— I have fallen in spite of every possible exertion eight days in arrear upon this journal, and must recover them by short minutes kept from day to day— At 4 I returned to bed, and lay without sleeping till six— They breakfast on board the boat at seven— It rained almost the whole of this day—confining us to the cabin, and depriving us of the sight of most of the views on the river— Our course up the river is as follows—

We passed by Galiopolis about 4 this morning, without seeing it, and reached Marietta, at half past 3 this afternoon. I had received invitations to visit Marietta, and landed there with the usual demonstrations of welcome, a great crowd of people—guns fired; bells rung and a procession to the presbyterian church, where an address of welcome was read by judge Putnam a son of General Rufus Putnam— In my answer, referring to the interest I had always taken in the city of Marietta, I related the incident of my visit to the Revd. Manasseh Cutler at his house in Ipswich hamlet, after his return from his visit to Marietta in 1788. and of my conversation with him concerning the Western Country at that time. And I said that from the time of that conversation, I had taken a deep interest in the whole West and watched its progress step by step to its present great and flourishing condition— These remarks were received apparently with lively satisfaction, and the shaking of hands, was with a heartier squeeze than almost anywhere else. After this ceremony, I took a short ride round the city, to visit the remarkable Indian Mounds in this place— There is no tradition indicating when, or by whom or for what purpose they were constructed, but they are very extensive and the central mound is about forty feet high, two hundred feet square at the base, and one hundred at the top, perfectly formal in its symmetry— There is an Article upon these works, by Dr Manasseh Cutler, in the first volume of the transactions of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. When we returned to the Steamer, a committee of 3 members, Ephraim Cutler Caleb Emerson, and Joseph Barker embarked with us to accompany us to Pittsburgh.— We became acquainted with more of our fellow passengers— Mr and Mrs Rogers with a boy of 10 or 12 years, and Mrs Harper of Baltimore— Cards— Whist— I left the table to converse with the Committeemen from Marietta. Lines to Miss Amanda M’Eleevy. Mrs Stillwell takes leave to land at Wheeling with a first and a last kiss.
16. II.50. Thursday.

Between 2 and 3 this morning we passed by Wheeling in Virginia, where many of our fellow passengers left us, and the deputation from Pittsburgh, Messrs. Denny, Bakewell, Eichbaum, Darragh and Stevens came, on board to meet us.— As we passed by Wheeling a gun was fired from our boat, and returned from the shore— There had been talk at Wheeling of inviting me to the place and giving me a reception— Many persons wished it and many thought an invitation had been sent to me but there was none— We passed equally by Steubenville in Ohio, and Beaver in Pennsylvania without notice.— The deputation from Pittsburgh had expected our arrival there to morrow morning, and all the arrangements had been made for a magnificent reception at that time Among the rest all the fire company association had held meetings and passed sundry Resolutions for having a grand display of their own; and Mr Brentlinger, as a deputation a copy of their Resolutions one of which was that I should be conducted to some public building where I was to be addressed in their name, and should be requested to deliver an Oration— And a temperance association, not to be behind hand with the firemen, had held meetings, and chosen a deputation to invite me to deliver an Oration upon Temperance— I delivered to Mr Brentlinger an answer declining to pronounce the Oration to the Firemen. I shall take the same course with the Temperance association— The Pittsburgh deputation were sadly disconcerted at our arrival before the time, and seriously proposed that we should land at Rapps settlement of Economy, pass the night there, and proceed to Pittsburgh to morrow in another Steamer to be sent down for us. But this project was abandoned, and at half past 3 in the afternoon we landed at Pittsburgh There was a considerable crowd of People assembled on the wharf to whom from the Steamer Mr Harmar Denny introduced me by name, and who received me with 3 cheers.— The Mayor of the City Mr Alexander Hay came on board to meet me, and at my own request, walked with me to the Exchange Hotel, followed by the crowd who were notified that the Procession and Reception would take place, to morrow morning, as it was regulated by the programme published in the newspapers of this day.— The multitude then after three cheers dispersed; but individuals were pressing in the whole evening. We had pressing Letters from Mr M’Kennon of Washington Pennsylvania, and from Mr Andrew Stewart of Uniontown, to know the precise moment when we shall arrive at those places. We first determined to go on Saturday to Washington; and on Monday to Uniontown; but on remonstrances from Mr Denny we concluded to remain over the Sunday at Pittsburgh, and to go on Monday to Washington, on Tuesday to Uniontown, and we wrote accordingly— Wednesday to Cumberland— Thursday home.
17. IV— V.15. Friday.

Debellare superbos— There is a special Providence in the fall of a Sparrow; and were it not itself arrogant self-sufficiency in me to believe, I should believe that this special Providence comes to pass for the chastisement of my pride and Vanity— The Scene of laying the corner Stone of the Astronomical observatory last week at Cincinnati, has been repeated with still more mortifying circumstances this day at Pittsburgh.— That Pageant was intended to promote the cause of Science in the minds of the People— It had a moral purpose—an important end to the attainment of which I heartily concurred— Had the day passed off successfully and without accident, the impression left on the minds of the Spectators and hearers would have been favourable to the accomplishment of the undertaking and honorary to me— The inexorable rain was literally a flood of cold water poured out on the whole ceremony. All was disappointment— But my duty and the purpose of the Society in their invitation to me were performed.— The Corner Stone of the Astronomical Observatory was laid, with supplication by me to the throne of Heaven that the erection of the building may be conducive to the improvement of the condition of man upon Earth— It is not for man to exult, even in his good intentions— It is his duty to bear disappointment, even of the best purposes with resignation and equanimity— The pageant of this day was of no earthly importance. It was ostensibly all honorary to me.— I had been invited by the city authorities to visit the city on my way to or from Cincinnati, and it was a reception— A large procession, at the head of which I was exhibited in a barouche with four handsome horses, accompanied by the Mayor of the City Mr Hay. Mr Harmar Denny and Mr Richard Biddle, started from the Exchange Hotel where we lodge, with military companies, martial music, and all the companies of the fireman’s association, in their respective showy and variegated uniforms, traversed through the abundant mud streams all the principal Streets of the City, with an heavy drenching rain pouring down all the time— We returned to the same Exchange, whence from an open balcony, Mr M’Candless delivered by heart the welcoming address of which he had sent me a copy. My answer was very short, apologizing for having come before the time, and declaring my unwillingness to detain them in the rain.— The procession then terminated; the crowd dispersed; but came up in squads to my chamber to shake hands with me through the whole day.
18. IV.45 Saturday.

I had renewed applications yesterday from the fireman’s association, who had determined at all events to have their torch light procession, and equally resolved to have an Oration from me; but I again declined— I did the same with the Temperance association, at the head of whose deputation judge Wilkins made the application to me. Judge Wilkins is a member of the approaching Congress elect, and told me he would leave home on Monday for Washington, and offered me a seat in his carriage which I declined for the engaments to visit Mr M’Kennon and Mr Stewart. I also received yesterday a large deputation from the Liberty party with an address and a request that I would meet, and address them.— This I declined on the ground of having been invited here, by the concurrence of all parties, I am interdicted from discoursing upon topics of deep party feeling—but in a speech of about 20 minutes, I gave my opinions without reserve on all the Slavery questions now in agitation— One of the members of the deputation brought me this day, a meagre and most imperfect abstract of part of my speech which he proposes to publish as a report of the speech. I reminded him of several most important omissions; and there were others which I did not notice— I received yesterday and this day, Letters informing me of my election as an honorary member of the Webster and Tilghman Literary Societies; to which I answered by Letters of acceptance— We had last evening a very elegant party and supper at Mr Harmar Denny’s— This morning I wrote from the time of rising until 8. upon my journal; and immediately after, with Mr Denny, Mr Biddle and Mr Grinnell I crossed the Monongahela, in the ferry boat, and visited Mr Lorenz’s Ironworks, and another establishment, where we saw the process of rolling and hammering iron—and the work of the red hot ball, hammered into a bloom, and the blast— Thence recrossing the river we ascended to the top of the Court house whence beautiful prospects were in view. The junction of the Monongahela and Allegany rivers—the Allegany city itself, and the hills all around Our next visit was to Captain Howard and the Iron ship on the Stocks which he is building for the Government— We saw one of the ribs of the ship fashioned from the Anvil— Thence we rode out to the U.S. Arsenal, about 3 miles from the City where we were received and temperately entertained by Captain and Mrs Harding The River Allegany flows beautifully in front of the building, and there is Washington’s Island.— I thought of my lamented nephew, Lieutt. T. B. Adams who was stationed three years. Returning to Pittsburgh, we visited the cotton factory of Mr Bakewell, and saw the spinning jennies, and heard the rattling of the spindes and the looms— Returned to the Exchange hotel at three.
19. IV— V.15. Sunday.

After returning to the Exchange Hotel at 3. p.m yesterday, I received the visits of Ladies and gentlemen indiscriminately, and shook hands with them all. Among the persons who have been the most kindly attentive to me here has been Mr Walter Forward, the late Secretary of the Treasury. He has two or three times mentioned to me that there would be some movement of Memorial here against the annexation of Texas to this Union. But I did not trust myself to speak freely with him— Mr Forward is a worthy well-meaning man, of considerable talent, and too pliable disposition— Not the Man of Iron mould that the Times require— Last evening after dark I went with Mr Grinnell and Mr Johnson to visit Miss Rhey one of our traveling companions from Cincinnati, who had sent me a beautiful bouquet of flowers, and had invited us, for last or this evening.— We saw her father mother, brothers and sisters, a respectable family in private life. She was not at home, when we called, but came in as we were taking leave.— We were followed in the dark by a number of persons from the exchange Hotel to Mr Rhey’s door.— We went to the Monongahela house to visit Mrs Campbell, and had not been there ten minutes, before Mr Hay the Mayor of the City, rushed in, and said that the fireman’s Association torch light procession were coming having collected and exhibited themselves in front of the Exchange hotel and finding me not there had followed me down. I went out upon the balcony and the Mayor announced me to the company.— I addressed them in a few words of thanks for the honour done me by them, and of excuse from physical disability, for declining a large discourse—after which they let me off with three bouncing cheers, while I heard a single voice saying—Mr Adams give us a speech— They then strolled off to Mr M’Candless’s house, where they called him out and exacted from him, a speech which he gave them and they dispersed— This morning Mr Denny came in his carriage, and took me to the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Heron preached from Matthew 5.14. “Ye are the light of the world.” We dined in the city of Allegany, with Coll. Robinson late an Agent of the U.S. Government to contract a loan in Europe, which did not succeed— We had a temperance dinner— No wine— And saw his wife—four grown sons and three daughters.— one son married—his wife and child. and Mr M’Candless.— Afternoon at the Exchange Hotel— James G. Moorhead, old antimason, and abolitionist editor of the Indiana, Pennsylvania—gave me a Letter to his son, a Clerk in the 4th. Auditor’s Office— Visit from judge Henry Baldwin. Evening with Mr M’Candless, at the high episcopal church. Revd Mr Uphold a Puseyite, read the Evening service for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Hebrews 12.25.

div.dateline: Pittsburgh. Monday 20. November 1843. Canonsburg. Washington Pennsa
div.p: 20. IV. Monday

We left Pittsburgh at 8 O’Clock this morning, for Washington Pennsylvania— My stay at Pittsburgh from Thursday last when we reached it has been tumultuary, honorary, and inexpressibly irksome. I had received from Pittsburgh at various times testimonials of sympathy which had already bound me in gratitude to the city; and I was pleased with an invitation which gave me the opportunity of expressing in person my gratitude to the People; but these mass meetings at which I find myself held up as a show, where the most fulsome adulation is addressed to me face to face in the presence of thousands, and where long premeditated written discourses are read to me, to be answered without a moment of reflection, all this is so adverse to my nature, that it has in a great measure solved the continuity of my existence, and I am like one coming out of a trance or a fainting fit unconscious of what has been passing around me. This morning Mr Ewing and Mr Reed the disputation who came to meet us at Pittsburgh, from Washington Pennsylvania, had provided for us an excellent Stage coach and travelled with us in it, with Mr Baird, Mr Hay the Mayor of Pittsburgh, and Mr Harmar Denny accompanied us over the Monongahela ferry, to the summit of the heights opposite the city, and there took leave of us.— To the unremitting kindness and attentions of these gentlemen during the whole of our visit here I have been under the greatest obligations— I answered last Evening a very earnest invitation from Somerset Pennsylvania with an enclosure fromPearson, which required a special Letter though Mr Pearson is a total stranger to me. I received also a Letter of invitation from the Mayor of Cumberland, Maryland through which we are to pass.— Our stage travel this day was the first we have had on this expedition— Tis only 25 miles from Pittsburgh to Washington; but it took us the whole day to travel them. Our first stage was to the halfway house— But nine miles short of Washington was Canonsburg and Jefferson College.— Here we met Mr M’Kennon, and a cavalcade from Washington, but Dr Brown the President of Jefferson College insisted upon my going to it; and there addressed me extemporaneously, and welcomed me in the name of the Officers and students to whom he introduced me— I answered the address and shook hands with the Students and others— Then returned to the Stage, and proceeded to Washington followed by the increasing files of horsemen coming out to meet us— Military company— Committee of reception. Exchange Hotel— Dinner—rain and mud.— Walk to the Court house—dense crowd of people— Address of welcome to me from the President of Washington College— My answer. Shake hands with the multitude— Walk to Mr M’Kennon’s house— Richard H Lee— Tea— Visit to the female Seminary— Address of Miss Foster, the principal teacher to me, my answer. Return to Mr M’Kennon’s. Party and Supper.
21— III— IV. Tuesday.

The Stamina of my Constitution, are sinking under the hardships, and exposures of traveling at this Season and at my time of life, aggravated by the continual overwhelming kindness of my political friends, and the empty honours, showered upon me ostensibly by the People as I pass along, but embracing only a part of the People, and carrying with it no solid permanent opinion.— They bring to my heart no feeling of Pride—to my mind no new or useful truth— Momentary joy, at the experience of kind treatment from my fellow men, and Vanitas vanitatum as spoke the inspired preacher.— O! Curas, hominum! o, quantum est in rebus inane! as spoke the Roman Poet; bring me to the only just conclusion, humble submission to divine Providence— My racking cough all last Night, left me scarce an hour of sleep, and no repose— I was up at 3 and again at 4. and wrote on the arrears of this Diary, from that time till 7 We breakfasted at Mr M’Kennon’s, and left his house in Stages at 8. in the midst of a heavy squall of thunder, lightning and snow.— We were accompanied by Mr Andrew Stewart, member elect to Congress from the District who came in last evening from Wheeling, and by two gentlemen, who also came last evening, with an invitation onto me to stop at Brownsville. I took leave of Mr M’Kennon, his wife, four sons and two daughters all of full age, or verging close upon it, and of Professor Richard Henry Lee, his two sons fine boys and daughter of about 15. Mr M’Kennon’s supper party last evening consisted of about 30 gentlemen, professors and teachers at the College and inhabitants of the vicinity, all well bred intelligent men.— He proposed to them in a temperate glass of wine the health and happiness of his guest, which they drank, and to which I responded by my thanks, and by giving the County of Washington, the town of Washington, and the College of Washington Pennsylvania. Success, Prosperity and happiness to all who belong to them. He then let me off to bed— This day we came 25 miles to Brownsville; where we dined; stopping ten minutes at Centreville on the way.— At Brownsville I was transferred to a Barouche— Procession— Dinner with a Roman Catholic Priest at the head of the table. The church, building, Procession to the Presbyterian church.— Address of welcome, by a young clergy man named Adams—a Cousin, descended from William Adams of Ipswich, son of the first Henry.— My Answer— Hand shaking—proceed 12 miles onto Uniontown— Transfer to a Barouche— Cavalcade escort— Military Company. Band of Music. Mud Ancle deep. Procession in Barouche and 4 to Presbyterian Church. Address of welcome excellent, byMy Answer— Take affectionate leave of Pennsylvania—political remarks— Shake hands— M’Lelland’s Hotel. Andrew Stewart takes leave of us— Spend the Evening in my chamber, alone, coughing and writing a day of this Diary.
22 I— III— V. Wednesday.

I passed a Night of torture, with a hacking and racking cough, and feverish head-ache— I went to bed at 9. and was up with fits of coughing at 11 at 1. at 3. and at 5 this morning, and finally lay till near 6. totally dispirited before I rose for the day.— We had 62 miles of hard stage riding over the National road to reach Cumberland. My expedient to husband my strength till I can get home, is abstinence— I took a Seidlitz powder; and ate nothing the whole day. Mr Cave Johnson, member-elect from Tennessee to the 28th. Congress, with his wife and an infant boy 2 years old, whom he called Tom Tucker, a Miss Dabney, Aaron Vail Brown, another re-elected member from Tennessee, Mr Jamison a member-elect from Missouri, and two other men came in last evening from Wheeling, and proceed with us this day, though in separate Stages to Cumberland We were confined to our own Stage. 62 miles over a rode frozen as hard as a granite rock—for the change from rain to hard frost, took place in the course of the last night, and this day we had January weather and a clear sky.— Mrs M Alister was traveling alone I had no acquaintance with her, but she accosted me with great civility and kindness. Said her husband and her father had both been warm friends and admirers of mine and of my father— We rode 32 miles to Keizers ridge, the highest peak of the Allegany Mountain 2500 feet above the level of the Monongahela river.— The cold was here so intense that I estimated Fahrenheit’s Thermometer at 20— Our company of the three stages dined here, but I fasted; and derived from it the benefit of relief from the headache, and lighter suffering from my other complaints— The country through which we travel is chiefly covered with wood— Oak and Chesnut principally, with very little of the evergreens or needle wood— Many of the trees are strait and disproportionately lofty to their size— None remarkably large— None equal in diameter to the old elm on Boston Common— The forests have the ragged appearance which defaces all the woodlands throughout this whole Country—lofty dead, blasted trees, standing as stumps the image of desolation Others half uprooted and half fallen, lying across the living trees adjoining them and marring their beauty— Others agroun, prostrate stretched along the ground, and entangling the way.— The woods are solitary too. Scarce a beast or a bird to be seen— Not even a Crow or a Rook— Our after dinner ride of 26. Miles to Cumberland was all descending; and about halfway, the Stage driver pointed out to us the dividing line, between Pennsylvania, and Maryland.— We reached Cumberland about 7. O’Clock. It was dark. There was a small gathering of People at the door of the hotel, who readily accepted the proposal to defer the reception till to-morrow morning

div.dateline: Cumberland. Thursday 23 November 1843. Harpers Ferry. Washington.
div.p: 23. II— III. V. Thursday.

Benjamin slept in my chamber. The night was not so distressing, as that in Uniontown, but still much afflicted— I went to bed soon after nine, and was awakened and roused by coughing fits at eleven, at two and at four this morning, with no conscious sleep in the intervals.— At four I rose, dressed and wrote till 7.— We travelled this day on the Railways from Cumberland to Washington city.— There was breakfast, of which I took a single cup of Coffee— Neither Mayor, nor committee of reception made their appearance—a number not large, perhaps a hundred of respectable looking men, and half as many boys, gathered at the hotel or followed me to the railway depot, and shook hands with me as I was seated in the Car— Just after Sun rise, at half past seven we started, and rodeMiles to Harper’s ferry to dinner— Mr Sidney Breese U.S. Senator from the State of Illinois was in the same Car with me; and spoke to me.— I did not recognize his person though I have seen him before, and have had some correspondence with him. Most of the country we came through this day was within the bounds of Virginia— A plain open champaign country, covered with alternate fields of pasture, and of green winter wheat just out of the ground— At Harpers ferry where we arrived about 2. p.m the offal of a train of Cars from Baltimore, was left for our party to dine upon— I found myself at table by the side of Benjamin Tappan U.S. Senator from Ohio, and Mr Wilkins member of the house elect, from Pittsburgh, spoke to me, and said I might have come with him in his carriage as he had offered me, but for my engagements on the road— Harper’s ferry I remember with pleasing and sad recollections of the Congress party from Georgetown, in the Iron canal boat on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, in June 1834.— It looks much now as it did then— We now proceed on the Baltimore and Ohio rail-way, pass Ellicott’s Mills with other reminiscences, and at the dusk of evening 5 p.m. reach the relay house and Thomas’s viaduct, nine miles from Baltimore— Here we land with our baggage from the Cars, which proceed forthwith to the monumental city. We wait half an hour for the Cars coming thence for Washington City—take our seats in them, and at half past 7. land safe at the foot of Capitol hill— James Stevens our mulatto waiter, was there in waiting with my Carriage— We went immediately to the Capitol, and Mr Grinnell marked his seat in the house of Representatives We went to Mrs Whitwell’s, but the house was shut, and no answer to bell or knocker— We came to my house in F. Street, where Benjamin Andrews had already arrived with our baggage. Found my wife and family well [symbols] and Walter Hellen with them— After tea, Mr Grinnell left us and went to lodge at Gadsby’s, and start at 6 to-morrow morning for New-Bedford.
24. III— IV.45 Friday.
[symbols]— I have performed my task

I have executed my undertaking, and am returned safe to my family and my home— It is not much in itself— It is nothing in the estimation of the world In my motives and my hopes it is considerable. The people of this Country do not sufficiently estimate the importance of patronizing and promoting Science as a principle of political action and the Slave oligarchy systematically struggle to suppress all public patronage or countenance to the progress of the mind— Astronomy has been specially neglected and scornfully treated— This invitation had a gloss of showy representation about it, that wrought more on the public mind than many volumes of dissertation or argument. I hoped to draw a lively and active attention to it among the people, and to put in motion a propelling power of intellect which will no longer stagnate into rottenness.— I indulge dreams of future improvement to result from this proclamation of popular homage to the advancement of Science, and am willing even to see my name perhaps ostentateously connected with a movement to which I so long and so anxiously strove to give an impulse in vain— For whatever of vain-glory there may be in this self approving reflection I pray to be forgiven— But I return to my home with the symptoms of speedy dissolution upon me— I had no conception of the extent to which I have been weakened by this Tussis Senilis—or Pneumonia Notha, or Old Mans cough— My strength is prostrated beyond any thing that I ever experienced before—even to total impotence— I have little life left in me, but it is my duty to cherish that which God has given me till it shall be his pleasure to take it back.— Mr Frye was here this morning, with papers relating to Mr Thomas Baker Johnson’s estate, and the Execution of his Will— Mr Johnson died on the 14th. of October last— He had constituted me by his last Will his sole Executor.— On receiving information at Quincy of his decease I wrote to Mr Frye enclosing a copy of the Will and requesting him to take all necessary measures with regard to the property here, till I should come— This morning I rode to the City Hall and presented the Will to the judge of the Orphan’s Court, Cassin for the probate. Judge Willam Cranch one of the witnesses to the Will, attested it and judge Cassin approved it— The Register Rotch made out a bond with two sureties, in a penalty of 1600 dollars, for the faithful execution of the Will— The bond to be executed by me, before Letters testamentary would be granted. The judge said he would then appoint two appraisers to be named by me to appraise the personal Estate— Dr Thomas was here, and prescribes for me pills and drops— Walter Hellen dined with us, and Mary Cutts was here this Evening. Despondency—but no Despair.
25. IV:30. Saturday.

A tolerable night— More undisturbed sleep, than I have had for many days before; but I never felt the prostration of strength more than this morning from my rising hour till breakfast.— I took a Seidlitz powder, and lay on the Sopha, all but lifeless— Dr Thomas was here morning and evening—prescribed potions and pills; and confined me to my chamber the whole day; a severer infliction than all his other remedies. Mr Frye and his son Dr Thomas Baker Johnson Frye, were here, and executed as sureties with me the Executor’s bond for the execution of Mr T. B. Johnson’s will given me yesterday by the Register of the Orphan’s Court, Rotch— Mrs Mary C. Adams, and Benjamin F. Andrews are the witnesses.— Mr Mosely the member elect from the New-York Buffalo District, visited me by card.— I wrote my two days of diary arrear. the 17th. and 18th. made the minutes for this day; and gave up the rest of the time to Idleness.— On the 2d. day of last May I left the house where I now write for my home at Quincy, Massachusetts.— I had been since the close of the 27th. Congress on the preceding 3d. of March, afflicted with this grave-yard cough— It had however subsided; but returned upon me for a fortnight, two days after my arrival at my sons house in Boston, on the 6th. of May. On the 16th. of that month I went out with his family to Quincy, where in the course of a week of quiet, the cough disappeared— On the 29th. of May I delivered before the Massachusetts historical Society in Boston, a discourse on the New-England confederacy of 1643. which I had written since leaving Washington. On the 4th. of July, 50 years after me, my son Charles Francis, delivered the Boston city Oration on the anniversary of our National Independence. I dated on this day, my Letter to the Committee at Bangor who had invited me to join them in celebrating the anniversary of the 1st. of August, the day of emancipation of the British West-India Negroes. On the 6th. of July, I left my home at Quincy, and returned to it on the 5th. of August, after an absence of one calendar month on a tour to Lebanon and Saratoga Springs Montreal, Quebec, Niagara Falls, and Western New-York— On the 24th. of October, I met and addressed my Constituents of the 8th Congressional District of Massachusetts, and in the Evening received the visit of Marshal Bertrand.— The Meeting with my Constituents was at Dedham. On the 25th. of October, I left my home at Quincy to lay the corner stone of an Astronomical Observatory at Cincinati, Ohio.
26. II.45. IV.15. Sunday.

My cough presses with renewed aggravation, and brought me up between two and three of the morning—and though I returned to bed, I enjoyed no further sleep— I went with my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, and William C. Johnson to the second presbyterian church and heard the Revd. Mr Knox preach from Psalm 51.14 [“]Deliver me from blood-guiltiness O God, thou God of my salvation; and my tongue shall sing aloud of thy righteousness.” He began by an exposition of the object of this Psalm, penitential and expiatory for the murder of Uriah— He dwelt with laudable vehemence on the atrocious nature of the crime, and supposed the contrition of David for having committed it deep and agonizing and gave the account of the transaction in all its horrid and disgusting details, and with a weight of censure upon David equally severe and uncompromising he turned upon his auditory, and charged us all with having blood guiltiness upon our souls; and then such fervent appeals to our consciences, such solemn expostulations, such terrific comminations, such awful forebodings, for the salvation of our souls, that I could scarcely account for my own insensibility— For our blood guiltiness consisted not in our own infidelity or indifference to the duties of religion, but in our remissness in our exertions to convert the impenitent sinners of our own families and firesides. We are responsible for their unrighteousness, and in suffering them to perish in their sins we are guilty of their blood, to all eternity— There is a fallacy in this reasoning so gross that it is inconceivable to me how it can make an impression upon any mind— This Mr Knox has been very recently setled here as the Pastor of this Presbyterian Church— The negotiation, with the Revd. Ezra Styles Ely, D.D. pending when I left this city last May, terminated unsuccessfully.— I did not attend the afternoon service— There was none at St. John’s Church, which is yet under repair, and Mr Hawley the rector is much indisposed.— Mr Frye was here. His son, the Doctor and Walter Hellen dined with us. Dr Thomas prescribed new potions added to the old— A mixture of boneset herb and snakeroot, infused in a pint of boiling water two hours—a tablespoonful to be taken warm three to four times a day. I received a Letter from my son, enclosing a deed to be executed by me and my wife to-morrow.— Also a Letter from Nathaniel Curtis, enclosing one of 3. Novr. 1843. from Petty Vaughan, London, and 3 sets of Bills of Exchange for £600, £500 and £400. dated 20. Novr 1843 on Petty Vaughan at 30 days sight in favour of——— I signed the bills, and enclosed them back to Mr Curtis— Received Letters also from H. Clay and D. Sears.
27. III.— IV.45. Monday.

My cough continues to excruciate me, Night and day. Dr Thomas visits me every day and prescribes a variety of slops and drops pills and pastes, lotions and potions, to all which hitherto the cough bids defiance I have Pease’s and other horehound candy jujube paste, molasses candy, and numerous other infallible remedies, and take them all, but the cough holds on— Mr Frye brought me the papers relating to the personal Estate of Mr Thomas B. Johnson, of which after his decease at my request he took possession and undertook the management, till I should come and take out the Letters Testamentary, which I did this day, and paid the Register, Rotch a bill for the papers hitherto issued— I named for Appraisers, Matthew St. Clair Clark and Peter Force and they were appointed— A notice of my having obtained Letters Testamentary, of the Orphan’s Court was given me, to be published 3 weeks in the National Intelligencer. I took it to that Office, and left it with Mr Gales. I had executed with my wife the deed yesterday received from my Son of South cove houselot, Boston toSwift, and it was to be acknowledged before David A. Hall, Commissioner of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for taking the acknowledgment of Deeds—and Justice of Peace— Fruitless search for him at the Courthouse, and thrice at his office. He finally came while we were at dinner and took our acknowledgments, and I enclosed the Deed to my Son. John G. Ladd, Boylston prize declaimer at Cambridge, the day after last Commencement— Visitor at Natick in November 1842—boy at Rossburg in 1828. came and solicited my influence to obtain for him employment as a clerk by some Committee of the house— A desperate adventure. He said he wanted to become a great man. Mr John W. Allen, heretofore a member of the house from Ohio, and whom on the first of this month we met at Cleveland was here with Mr Henry L. Ellsworth the Commissioner of Patents. Mr Allen is here but for a day or two— Mr Hamilton W. Pierson a Tract Society agent and home missionary, informed me, that there would be next Tuesday evening a meeting of the friends of this cause, which he invited me to attend, and to address a few remarks to the company which I declined. Dr Joseph Sewall was here, recently returned from his medical tour to England, Scotland, Ireland, France, Italy, Switzerland, Germany, Belgium, Holland, all since last April— Note from Genl. Almonte—asking an interview.
28 II.45— IV.45 Tuesday

Up again in the Night. My Cough is more urgent Mrs Adams prepared an obituary incription for the gravestone of her brother Thomas Baker Johnson, Son of Joshua and Catherine Johnson born at Nantes in France 7. Septr 1779. died at Washington D.C. 14 Octr 1843, aged 64 years, loved and lamented by his family.— The burial is to be in the Rock creek churchyard— I rode to Mr Matthew St. Clair Clark’s house, but he was at the Capitol and I followed him there— I presented to him the warrant of appraisement to him and Mr Force, which he said they would execute at 10 O’Clock to morrow morning. I bespoke of Mr M’Cormick the Postmaster some Letter paper and other Stationary.— Returning from the Capitol, I stop’d at Miss Polk’s and paid a visit to Mr Mosely the member elect from the Buffalo, District New-York, who gave me some dutch Lozenges, and talked about the election of Speaker of the House. He said he was informed there was yesterday a long interview between William Wilkins, and Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina, at which Mr Wilkins was offered the Speakers Chair, upon condition that he shall organize the Committees to the taste of the Slavemonger’s— This is the desperation of Calhounism— Rhett is the man who oiled the palm of Cushing to make him chairman of the Committee of Foreign Affairs in my place. On my way home I stop’d at Mr Peter Force’s Office, and informed him of his appointment as the second Appraiser of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s effects, and he promised to meet Mr Clark at 10 O’Clock to-morrow morning at the house and make the appraisement— Walk home— Evening visit from Mr Richard M. Cutts— And from Walter Hellen. General Don Juan N. Almonte, the Mexican Minister Plenipotentiary had requested of me by note a personal interview to make to me a communication as he had been ordered. I appointed between 6 and 7. O’Clock this Evening, which time he had suggested, to receive him— He came and delivered to me a copy of a Letter of Instructions from Mr Bocanegra, the Mexican Minister of foreign Affairs, dated 18. March 1843 ordering General Almonte, in an official visit to me, to tender to me the thanks of the Mexican Government and Nation, for the candour, generosity of my conduct towards Mexico, both in the Congress of the United States, and at Meetings of the People— I said I was happy to receive this testimonial of the approbation of the Mexican Government of my endeavours to promote peace and harmony, between the two countries, and to observe the Law of Justice, on the part of my Country towards Mexico, and all other Nations.
29. IV.45. Wednesday.

I made this morning the draught of a Resolution, which I propose to offer to the House of Representatives at the approaching Session of Congress— A Session at which a trial of character more severe than I ever before experienced awaits me; and from which may the Mercy of God deliver me to the judgment of the after age, pure and unsullied. Clouds and darkness are before me— Doctor Cassin the judge of the Orphan’s Court called on me and spoke of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s Will, which he said was a very good one— He said he had not required a bond of me, for double the amount of the fund of 45000 dollars bequeathed to my Son, at Boston, to be disposed of according to the provisions of the Will, because the property being in the State of Massachusetts was out of his jurisdiction, and being bequeathed in special trust to my Son, he did not see that the Executor had anything to do with it— If controversy should arise, it was a case for chancery jurisdiction in Massachusetts, but perhaps it might be proper to deposit a copy of the Will, in the Registry of Probate at Boston— I went to the House where Mr T. B. Johnson last resided and in which he died; and found Mr Clark and Mr Force engaged in appraising the household furniture horses and carriages— Mr Frye was with them. Mr Frye had taken a complete inventory of the Articles, and the Appraisers were using it to make their return.— After staying there some time I came home They finished their appraisement at 2. P.M. and Mr Frye was afterwards here— Likewise his Son the Doctor and Walter Hellen.— I received a Letter from Mr Grinnell, who reached his home at New-Bedford Sunday Morning at half past 7.— He has been a most kind and faithful friend to me on my late expedition— My Resolution is for the appointment of a Committee to ascertain the number of Slave owners throughout the Union, and the value of the property represented bymembers in the house and a proportional number in the electoral Colleges. General Almonte sent me a number of Newspapers— He told me that on the third of this month he had addressed a note to the Secretary of State a protest against the annexation of Texas to the United States, and that the correspondence which ensued, closed about ten days since— The Madisonian is full of premonitory symptoms of the proposition for the annexation of Texas. Mr. W. C. Johnson made a copy of the Will of T. B. Johnson, for Mr John Pope.
30. II— IV:45. Thursday

I received the key of Mr T. B. Johnson’s house, and Mr Frye sent me a small hair trunk, of which he gave me the key, and which contains the silver plate, and also sundry miniatures and other trinkets not to be included in the sale— Morning visit from Elisha R. Potter one of the members of the house from the State of Rhode-Island— I received at the Washington Bank 60. for one quarter’s interest due 1. Octr. last on 4000 dollars, Washington City Corporation 6 per Cents, and at the City hall 52.50 for interest due 1. July last on 3500 dollars.— And at the Franklin Insurance company, the half yearly dividend on my Stock in that company, due on the 1st. of November. Mrs John Adams, and her daughter Mary Louisa, with William C. Johnson, dined and spent the Evening with Doctor Frye, at his father’s house— Mrs Thornton was here in the Evening, and General Daniel Parker, who told me, that among the Documents to be produced in justification of the message proposing the annexation of Texas to the United States was a correspondence of Andrew Jackson, written in a better than his ordinary Style, referring to communications made to him in 1831 or 1832 by George W. Erving, implicating me for the transfer of the Negotiation of the Florida Treaty from Madrid to Washington, in 1818— This is another Mississippi Navigation conspiracy—and George W. Erving is to be the Jonathan Russell of that Negotiation— Mr Giddings of Ohio came, and introduced Perley B. Johnson, a new member from Ohio, and John Dickey also a member new, from Pennsylvania— We had much conversation upon the projected annexation of Texas— Mr Giddings said he hoped Tyler would recommend it in the Message, for that would be the surest way to render it universally odious. In the Madisonian of last Monday, the Bull of Pope Gregory the 16th. of 3. December 1839. is published in Latin, with an English Translation, and with an introduction signed Roane descanting upon the transcendant importance of the paper, and promising an examination, of every part of it.— This idea is infectious— The quarter from which it comes is passing strange; but an analytical review of the Bull, might be made of vast benefit to the cause of Liberty.

Day— Several months have passed away, without any summary record at their close of the regular manner of passing my time during their progress— Two months of daily travel, and two elaborate Orations, have cut up my Summer into driblets— But I have risen the whole Season through between 4 and 5. and after an hour or hour and a half of dressing, have written till breakfast— The incidents of travel occupied the remainder of the day for the two months; and in the intervals when I have been at home the composition of my discourses has absorbed all my hours— Since my return here, my disease has not disabled me for my usual employments, but they have been confined to the recovery of the arrears of this Diary; nine days of which had crept in—now redeemed.
